head.title: New York Schools Are Already Policed; Forced to Volunteer

hedline.hl1: New York Schools Are Already Policed; Forced to Volunteer

abstract.p: Letter by Thomas O'Brien, director of research at Horizon Institute for Policy Solutions, favors civics requirement in schools, either in form of community service or study of civic duty (Sept 13 article)

block.p: Your Sept. 13 Week in Review article on mandatory community service requirements in the Chicago school system highlights some of the problems with this plan but offers few alternatives.
Your Sept. 13 Week in Review article on mandatory community service requirements in the Chicago school system highlights some of the problems with this plan but offers few alternatives.

Today, only 15 percent of all schools require that students do any public service. If every student were allowed to write a major report on civic duty in lieu of performing community service, schools would be much more likely to add a civic requirement to their curriculums. Moreover, giving students this option would eliminate the legal problems involved in requiring direct community service.

If all schools had a civic requirement, students would become much more imbued with the ethic of community service, and this army of new activists would provide huge social benefits where the need is greatest.
The writer is director of research, Horizon Institute for Policy Solutions.
